text: he's got away from his jack trade you're
right mr. Hillman he's gone science
fiction dystopias tend to be orderly
highly administered places and stories
set in those places tend to be
allegories with neat accessible well
packaged meanings not so with Terry
Gilliam's Brazil which is extravagant
visionary and maybe just a little bit
crazy he tells the story of Sam played
by Jonathan Pryce a low level government
functionary and inveterate daydreamer it
can be hard sometimes to distinguish
between his dreams and the reality that
he lives in because that reality is
itself so completely fantastical
it's a rigidly controlled even
repressive society disrupted by frequent
acts of terrorism and held together by
an intricate maze of tubes pipes and
wires the physical contours of this
world are fully and brilliantly realized
Gilliam draws on elements of film noir
German Expressionism international style
architectural modernism and infuses
everything with his own quirky energy he
gets a lot of help from the cast
including fellow Monty Python alum
Michael Palin Trebek ah a handful of
first-rate British thespians and
strangest of all Robert De Niro as a
maverick electrician and plumber I came
into this game for the action the
excitement go anyway travel light
get in get out wherever this trouble a
man along the plot and the themes of
this movie are as tangled and convoluted
as some of the sets but order and
coherence are not what Terry Gilliam is
interested in in fact they represent
everything he fights against what are we
going to do with you a movie that exalts
the unfettered imagination will never
completely make sense but that's one of
the things that makes Brazil so
exhilarating
what is Brazil it's a song that plays in
this movie it's an enchanted faraway
place it was at the time this film was
made a country still in the grip of a
military dictatorship perhaps we can
find a clue about what terry gilliam
meant in this intriguing and elusive
movie if we recall that country's
unofficial motto Brazil is the land of
the future and it always will be
